Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: P2C2 -- Statistical estimation of past ice sheet volumes from paleo-sea level records
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PIs propose to develop a statistical model for inferring past mean global sea level (GSL) and ice sheet volumes from geological indicators of changes in local sea levels. This model will employ a Bayesian statistical framework to combine geological observations and their uncertainties with a geophysical model of the spatial and temporal sea level patterns associated with different meltwater sources. The proposed work focuses on three specific applications:
(1) evaluating the contribution of different ice sheets to high GSL during the Last Interglacial stage, ~130-115 thousand years ago;
(2) assessing ice sheet history from the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM) to the present, in particular estimating the net ice volume change across this time interval and assessing the relative contributions of the Laurentide and Antarctic ice sheets to meltwater pulse 1a at ~14.3 thousand years ago; and
(3) over a broader sweep of the Quaternary and Pliocene, investigating the relationship between Northern and Southern hemisphere ice volumes and paleoclimate proxies.

The geological record of past ice sheet responses to climate change can serve as a key data source for testing forward physical models of ice sheet dynamics under different climate scenarios. The model developed in this project will be an effort to synthesize such a data set, evaluate its associated uncertainties, and employ it to strengthen understanding of the relationship between key climate parameters (such as polar and circum-polar temperatures) and ice sheet stability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Earth’s climate is rapidly changing, with ensuing consequences for global and regional sea levels. Warmer oceans expand in volume; melting glaciers and ice sheets increase global mean sea level while affecting regional sea level in an uneven way around the world; and a changing climate can also influence regional sea level through its effects on ocean circulation and on winds. The geological record of past sea-level changes in response to past climate changes can provide a key source of insights and data for testing models of how sea level will respond in the future.

This project developed a set of statistical and geophysical tools for interpreting records of past sea-level changes and their relationship to global-average temperature. It applied these tools to study geological records of sea level during several important intervals over the last 130,000 years, with key findings including:

  • During the Last Interglacial stage, about 125,000 years ago, when global mean sea level was extremely likely at least 6.4 meters (21 feet) higher than today and global mean temperature about 1-2°C higher than the pre-Industrial, global mean sea-level exhibited at least two major peaks. It is likely (67% probability) that there was a period during the LIG in which GSL rose at a 1000-yr average rate of sea-level rise that exceeded 3 m (10 ft) per thousand years (kyr), but unlikely (33% probability) that the rate exceeded 7 m/kyr (23 ft/kyr) (Figure 1).
  • This grant produced a new database of geological sea-level records for the last ~3,000 years, as well as the first estimate of global sea-level (GSL) change over this time period to be based upon statistical synthesis of a global database of regional sea-level reconstructions. Global sea level varied by about ±8 cm (±3”) over the pre-Industrial Common Era, with a notable decline over 1000–1400 CE coinciding with ∼0.2 °C of global cooling. The 20th century global sea-level rise was extremely likely (95% probability) faster than global sea-level rise during any of the 27 previous centuries (Figure 2).
  • From 1901 to 1990, global mean sea level rose at a rate of 1.2 ± 0.2 mm/yr (0.4 ft/century). This estimate is slightly lower than indicated by earlier studies, including the 1.5 ± 0.2 mm/yr (0.5 ft/century) assessed by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change’s Fifth Assessment Report (AR5). Based on individual contributions tabulated in AR5, this estimate closes the twentieth-century sea-level budget. From 1993 to 2010, consistent with past estimates, global mean sea level rose at 3.0 ± 0.7 mm/yr (1.0 ft/century). As a consequence, this suggest that the acceleration in sea level over the past quarter century is greater than previously thought (Figure 3).

A set of statistical analysis routines for interpreting paleo-sea level proxy records was developed under this proposal (http://www.github.com/bobkopp/CESL-STEHM-GP) and has been used in regional paleo-sea-level reconstructions for the Carolinas, Florida, the Caribbean, Cascadia, and the Delaware estuary.

Statistical approaches developed under this grant informed the development of a global set of probabilistic, localized sea-level rise projections (Figure 4). The sea-level rise projections framework has been used to inform a number of sets of state and municipal projections around the country, as well as a national assessment of future coastal flood risk.
